newsitem.title: CANADA: Thousands more evacuate from Red River flood.
newsitem.headline: Thousands more evacuate from Red River flood.

text.p: Officials ordered another 4,200 residents of Winnipeg to evacuate by Tuesday night amid fears a hastily built dike in the south of the city may buckle under the pressure of the flooding Red River.

"The water has reached a certain level and we will no longer take risks with people," Winnipeg Mayor Susan Thompson said as she issued an evacuation order to south end residents threatened by the worst flood in 145 years.
Winnipeg, Manitoba's capital and largest city, has 650,000 residents.

Twenty miles (32 km) south at Ste. Agathe, 37 emergency workers were rescued by soldiers after a dike breach early on Tuesday submerged the town under six feet (two metres) of silty brown Red River water. No one was injured, Emergency Management Organisation spokeswoman Cynthia Webster said.
Ring dikes around seven other towns held, she added.

Peter Doerksen, 58, was one of the last of Ste. Agathe's 477 people to flee when walls of water crashed through the dike and flooded the town in 45 minutes. "When Grand Forks got hit, it was an unbelievable scenario then when you saw it on TV and read about it. This could not supposedly happen in Manitoba. It did," Doerksen said.
Dike breaches in Grand Forks, North Dakota, forced 90 percent of the city's 50,000 residents from their homes 10 days ago.
Some 17,000 Manitobans have been forced from their homes in towns and farms in the region. More than 4,200 evacuees have sought refuge at a Winnipeg sports arena.

Laura Rance prepared to evacuate after she was ordered to leave her home in Sanford, southwest of Winnipeg, by Tuesday night along with 2,000 other rural residents. "People are really anxious. We weren't supposed to get water here so there's a sense of injustice. This took people by surprise," Rance said after moving furniture from her basement.

Her home and Winnipeg's south end were defended by a 25-mile (40 km) earthen wall being thrown together just south of Sanford, but engineers feared it might not withstand the onslaught of what is now being called "The Red Sea."

Work crews began reinforcing a highway surrounding the city as a last line of defence for 10,000 people living in the city's southwest. In other parts of the city, Winnipeggers put their faith in a massive ditch built in 1968 to divert high Red River waters around its limits. The ditch was built after a flood in 1950 forced the evacuation of 100,000 people.

People forced from their southern Manitoba homes streamed in to register with the Red Cross for flood relief and temporary accommodations at a Winnipeg sports arena where families, many of whose houses and businesses were swamped, were given food, health care and vouchers to buy groceries.

Blake Scott, one of many city employees coordinating the evacuation centre, said the upheaval had left most people tense and weary. "Some people have been worried about the river itself -- they've been working in it, around it. They're worried about their families, where they are going to stay, eating -- their liveihood is not there right now," Scott said.
